The ratio test (also known as d'Alembert's ratio test)

The below test, which is one of the most useful and widely used convergence tests, applies only to series of positive terms.

Key Point

The Ratio Test 

Let \(\displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^{\infty} a_p} \) be a series of positive terms such that, as \(p\) increases, the limit of \(\dfrac{a_{p+1}}{a_p}\) equals a number \(\lambda\). That is \(\displaystyle{\lim_{p \to \infty} \dfrac{a_{p+1}}{a_p} = \lambda}\).

It can be shown that:

  • if \(\lambda >1 \quad\) then  \(\displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^{\infty} a_p }\) diverges.
  • if \(\lambda<1 \quad \) then  \(\displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^{\infty} a_p }\) converges. 
  • if \(\lambda = 1 \quad\) then  \(\displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^{\infty} a_p} \) may converge or diverge.

    That is, the test is inconclusive in this case.

Example

Use the ratio test to examine the convergence of the series

  1. \(\displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^\infty a_p=} 1 + \dfrac{1}{2!} + \dfrac{1}{3!} + \dfrac{1}{4!}+ \dots\)
  2. \( \displaystyle{\sum_{p=1}^\infty b_p=}1 + x^2 + x^3  + \dots\)
    3.  

Solution

  1. The general term in this series is \(\dfrac{1}{p!}\) i.e. \[ 1+ \dfrac{1}{2!} + \dfrac{1}{3!} + \dots = \sum_{p=1}^{\infty} \dfrac{1}{p!} \] So \[ a_p = \dfrac{1}{p^2} \quad \therefore \quad a_{p+1} = \dfrac{1}{(p+1)!}\] and the ratio \[\dfrac{a_{p+1}}{a_p} = \dfrac{p!}{(p+1)!}= \dfrac{p(p-1) \dots (3)(2)(1)}{(p+1)p(p_1) \dots (3)(2)(1)}= \dfrac{1}{p+1}\] \[\therefore \quad \lim_{p \to \infty} \dfrac{a_{p+1}}{a_p} = \lim_{p \to \infty} \dfrac{1}{p+1} = 0\] Since \(0<1\) the series is convergent. In fact, it can be shown that \[1 + \dfrac{1}{2!} + \dfrac{1}{3!} + \dots = e - 1 \approx 1.718\]
  2. Here we must assume that \(x > 0\) since we can only apply the ratio test to a series of positive terms. Now \[ 1 + x + x^2 + x^3 + \dots = \sum_{p=1}^{\infty} x^{p-1}\] so that \[b_p=x^{p-1}, \quad a_{p+1} = x^p\] and \[ \lim_{p \to \infty} \dfrac{b_{p+1}}{a_p} = \lim_{p \to \infty} \dfrac{x^p}{x^{p+1}} = \lim_{p \to \infty} x = x\] Thus, using the ratio test we deduce that (if \(x\) is a positive number) this series will only converge if \(x < 1\). We will see in a later Section that \[1+x+x^2+x^3+\dots = \dfrac{1}{1-x} \qquad \text{provided} \; 0<x<1\]
